note.title: CONDITIONALLY ADAPTIVE CSS. BROWSER BEHAVIOR THAT MIGHT IMPROVE YOUR PERFORMANCE

pageProps.body:
CONDITIONALLY ADAPTIVE CSS. BROWSER BEHAVIOR THAT MIGHT IMPROVE YOUR PERFORMANCE

https://pepelsbey.dev/articles/conditionally-adaptive/

Thereâ€™s a component structure behind every website or app these days, hundreds of small files. Though when it comes to delivering resources, we often serve just a single file for every resource type: styles, scripts, and even sprites for images. Everything gets squashed during the build process, including resources specific to certain resolutions or media conditions.

And resources arenâ€™t equal! For example, CSS is a blocking resource, and thereâ€™s nothing for a browser to render until every last byte of every CSS file is loaded. Why? The last line of a CSS file could overwrite something that came just before that. Thatâ€™s your â€œCâ€ in the CSS, which stands for â€œcascade.â€

WhatÂ if?

WhatÂ if weâ€™d take the CSS bundle weâ€™ve just built out ofÂ dozens ofÂ files and split itÂ back into multiple parts? But this time, based onÂ conditions where these parts are applicable. For example, weÂ could split itÂ into four files:

  • Base: universal styles with fonts and colors
  • Mobile: styles only for narrow viewports
  • Tablet: styles only for medium viewports
  • Desktop: styles only for large viewports
<link rel="stylesheet" href="base.css" />
<link rel="stylesheet" href="mobile.css" media="(max-width: 767px)" />
<link
  rel="stylesheet"
  href="tablet.css"
  media="(min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1023px)"
/>
<link rel="stylesheet" href="desktop.css" media="(min-width: 1024px)" />

Priorities

Another little detail inÂ the Network panel made meÂ realize what was goingÂ on: the Priority column. You might have toÂ enable itÂ byÂ right-clicking the table heading and choosing itÂ from the list ofÂ available columns.

ItÂ will also require you toÂ write your CSS inÂ aÂ way that isolates styles for different viewports. Thatâ€™s another idea for anÂ article, byÂ theÂ way. The same goes for tooling: itâ€™s not quite thereÂ yet. The closes thing IÂ could find are Media Query plugin for Webpack and Extract Media Query plugin for PostCSS.

Preferences

The list ofÂ media features you can use inÂ Media Queries extends beyond just viewport width and height. You can adapt your website toÂ the userâ€™s needs and preferences: color scheme, pixel density, reduced motion, etc. But not only that! With this new behavior inÂ mind, weÂ can make sure that only relevant styles are render-blocking.

Color scheme

One ofÂ the most popular media features these days isÂ prefers-color-scheme, which allows you toÂ supply light and dark color schemes toÂ match the userâ€™s system preferences. InÂ most cases, itâ€™s used right inÂ CSS asÂ @media, but itÂ can also beÂ used toÂ link relevant CSS files conditionally.

<link rel="stylesheet" href="light.css" media="(prefers-color-scheme: light)" />
<link rel="stylesheet" href="dark.css" media="(prefers-color-scheme: dark)" />

And just like weâ€™ve learned before, browsers will load dark.css with the lowest priority inÂ the case when the user prefers aÂ light color scheme and vice versa. Thereâ€™s aÂ good article byÂ Thomas Steiner diving deep into the dark mode, including aÂ theme toggler that works with CSS files linked thisÂ way.

Pixel density

Sometimes weÂ have toÂ deal not with beautiful vector graphics, but with raster imagesÂ too. InÂ this case, weÂ often have different files for different pixel densities, for example, icon.png and _icon@2x.png_.

a {
  display: block;
  width: 24px;
  height: 24px;
  background-image: url("icon.png");
}
@media (min-resolution: 2dppx) {
  a {
    background-image: url("icon@2x.png");
    background-size: 24px 24px;
  }
}

These six lines ofÂ CSS specifically targeting high-density screens are usually bundled into the same file loaded for users with low-density screens. Fortunately, browsers are smart enough not toÂ load high-density graphics. You guessed it, weÂ can doÂ itÂ even better: split them into aÂ separate file and load itÂ with the lowest priority.

<link rel="stylesheet" href="retina.css" media="(min-resolution: 2dppx)" />

This file will beÂ loaded and applied immediately ifÂ the user decides toÂ drag the browser window toÂ aÂ high-density screen. But itÂ wonâ€™t block the initial rendering onÂ aÂ low-density screen.

Reduced motion

Animations and smooth transitions could improve user experience, but for some people they can beÂ aÂ source ofÂ distraction orÂ discomfort. The media feature prefers-reduced-motion allows you toÂ wrap your heavy motion inÂ @media toÂ give users aÂ choice. ByÂ the way, â€œreduceâ€ doesnâ€™t mean â€œdisableâ€, itâ€™s upÂ toÂ you toÂ create aÂ comfortable environment and not sacrifice clarity atÂ the same time.

<link
  rel="stylesheet"
  href="animation.css"
  media="(prefers-reduced-motion: no-preference)"
/>

Instead, you can put your motion-heavy styles into aÂ separate file that will beÂ loaded with the lowest priority when the user prefers reduced motion. The best way toÂ achieve this would beÂ toÂ extract all the matching @media during the build process.
